blogs.title: Task Runners and Browserify
blogs.post: This week, we learned about Task Runners and Browserify. Browserify is a tool for compiling node-flavored common js modules for the browser. Browserify is helping organize your code and use third-party libraries. If you need to install any packages it is easy to do with npm.  This is something that I've been working with before so I felt pretty confident about new topic. Same day we begin to use Grunt, the java script Task Runner. When you running grunt it helps to keep your code very clean and well organized, grunt will tell you in terminal window if you have any errors so you can alway fix them. Thus, it will help to compile code with the less stress. Less stress they say... but it's not about me. For some reason Task Runner in not friendly to me. In class  we begin new project, I was following my teacher's code and was running grunt in my lib folder, but terminal would show me  so many errors that I was not able to fixe all of them and follow my instructor at the same time. That night I left class very frustrated...

blogs.title: Bootstrap
blogs.post: This past week, we learned about Bootstrap. Bootstrap is a free and open-source front-end library for designing websites and web applications. It's templates that are made base on HTML and CSS. It's come in handy if you need to build an responsive app or website but you don't really have time for that. In this case Bootstrap is an awesome tool to know. To use this library is super easy, first step is: Copy-paste the stylesheet <link> into your <head> before all other stylesheets to load our CSS. Then, Copy-paste two more links, jQuery first, then Bootstrap JS. Place the following <script>s near the end of your pages, right before the closing </body> tag, to enable them. That's it, Bootstrap is ready for use. To begin work with the library, simply copy class that will feet your new project and paste it in to your html structure.

blogs.title: XHR
blogs.post: Last week we were going through XHR request and Callback Functions. XHR is a way to get data back from a server, but under the hood to get data back usually take some time. In this case we need to use Callback Functions that allow us to run code synchronously. I use XHR Request in my project “Solar System”. I stored data for the app in JSON file. Why JSON? Because when exchanging data between a browser and a server, the data can only be text. JSON is text, and we can convert any JavaScript object into JSON, and send JSON to the server.We can also convert any JSON received from the server into JavaScript objects.This way we can work with the data as JavaScript objects, with no complicated parsing and translations.

blogs.title: Travel Diary
blogs.post: Last week I started new project Travel Diary with my awesome team Venus Flytrap. The main goal was to create array of objects then print each object to the DOM. Also, each object supposed to have an input section that would aloud user to add notes. Moreover, every time user add note it would appear at the bottom of the page as a new separate box which would include note itself and country location. During this project I was struggling with pulling specific data from input and printing it to the notes section. I spend whole day trying to figure out how to deal with it. Finally I decided to take a break...Magic happen during my break. I suddenly realize that I can use data attributes that would aloud me to store and reuse specific information. Lesson learned: if you stuck on coding then it’s time to take a break.
